Mediation Analysis

Source: vignettes/mediation.qmd

Mediation analysis (Yuan and MacKinnon 2009) allows researchers to investigate the mechanism by which an independent variable (XX) influences a dependent variable (YY). Rather than just asking “Does X affect Y?”, mediation asks “Does X affect Y through an intermediate variable M?”

Common examples include:

  • Psychology: Does a therapy (XX) reduce anxiety (MM), which in turn improves sleep quality (YY)?
  • Medicine: Does a new drug (XX) lower blood pressure (MM), thereby decreasing the risk of heart attack (YY)?

In this vignette, we demonstrate how to estimate a simple mediation model using INLAvaan. We will fit a standard three-variable mediation model:

  • aa: The effect of XX on MM.
  • bb: The effect of MM on YY.
  • cc: The direct effect of XX on YY.
  • a×ba \times b: The indirect effect (the mediation effect).

In a mediation model, the Total Effect represents the overall impact of XX on YY, ignoring the specific pathway. It answers the question: “If I change XX, how much does YY change in total, regardless of whether it goes through MM or not?”.

Data Simulation

To verify that INLAvaan recovers the correct parameters, we simulate data where the “truth” is known. The logic is as follows: Generate…

  1. XX normally;
  2. MM dependent on XX with a coefficient of 0.5; and
  3. YY dependent only on MM with a coefficient of 0.7.

Critically, we do not add XX to the generation of YY. This means the true direct effect (cc) is 0, and the relationship is fully mediated. We expect our model to estimate a≈0.5a \approx 0.5, b≈0.7b \approx 0.7, and the indirect effect ab≈0.35ab \approx 0.35. The direct effect cc should be close to zero.

set.seed(11)
n <- 100  # sample size

# 1. Predictor
X <- rnorm(n)

# 2. Mediator (Path a = 0.5)
M <- 0.5 * X + rnorm(n)

# 3. Outcome (Path b = 0.7, Path c = 0)
Y <- 0.7 * M + rnorm(n) 

dat <- data.frame(X = X, Y = Y, M = M)

Model Specification and Fit

The standard lavaan syntax for a mediation model is straightforward (note the use of the := operator to define the indirect effect as a new parameter.):

mod <- "
  # Direct effect (path c)
  Y ~ c*X

  # Mediator paths (path a and b)
  M ~ a*X
  Y ~ b*M

  # Define Indirect effect (a*b)
  ab := a*b

  # Define Total effect
  total := c + (a*b)
"

The model is fit using asem(). The meanstructure = TRUE argument is supplied to estimate intercepts for the variables.

library(INLAvaan)
fit <- asem(mod, dat, meanstructure = TRUE)
#> ℹ Finding posterior mode.
#> ✔ Finding posterior mode. [32ms]
#> 
#> ℹ Computing the Hessian.
#> ✔ Computing the Hessian. [88ms]
#> 
#> ℹ Performing VB correction.
#> ✔ Performing VB correction. [255ms]
#> 
#> ℹ Using skew normal approximation.
#> ⠙ Fitting skew normal to 0/7 marginals.
#> ✔ Fitting skew normal to 7/7 marginals. [363ms]
#> 
#> ⠙ Computing ppp and DIC.
#> ⠹ Computing ppp and DIC.
#> ✔ Computing ppp and DIC. [1.4s]
#>

The user may wish to specify different prior distributions for the parameters. See the relevant section in the Get started vignetted for further details.

Results

The summary output provides the posterior mean, standard deviation, and 95% credible intervals for all paths.

summary(fit)
#> INLAvaan 0.2.1.9000 ended normally after 5 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                      BAYES
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         7
#> 
#>   Number of observations                           100
#> 
#> Model Test (User Model):
#> 
#>    Marginal log-likelihood                    -311.923 
#>    PPP (Chi-square)                              0.559 
#> 
#> Information Criteria:
#> 
#>    Deviance (DIC)                              568.757 
#>    Effective parameters (pD)                     6.919 
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>    Marginalisation method                     SKEWNORM
#>    VB correction                                  TRUE
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate       SD     2.5%    97.5%     NMAD    Prior       
#>   Y ~                                                                          
#>     X          (c)   -0.060    0.120   -0.296    0.176    0.001    normal(0,10)
#>   M ~                                                                          
#>     X          (a)    0.525    0.109    0.311    0.740    0.000    normal(0,10)
#>   Y ~                                                                          
#>     M          (b)    0.769    0.101    0.571    0.966    0.000    normal(0,10)
#> 
#> Intercepts:
#>                    Estimate       SD     2.5%    97.5%     NMAD    Prior       
#>    .Y                -0.070    0.100   -0.266    0.126    0.000    normal(0,32)
#>    .M                 0.126    0.100   -0.071    0.323    0.000    normal(0,32)
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate       SD     2.5%    97.5%     NMAD    Prior       
#>    .Y                 0.975    0.144    0.732    1.297    0.004 gamma(1,.5)[sd]
#>    .M                 0.998    0.147    0.749    1.325    0.004 gamma(1,.5)[sd]
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate       SD     2.5%    97.5%     NMAD    Prior       
#>     ab                0.401    0.101    0.218    0.596                         
#>     total             0.331    0.129    0.060    0.573

Looking at the Regressions and Defined Parameters sections of the output:

  • Both intercepts are non-significant, since we simulated data with true means of zero.
  • Path aa (M ~ X) estimated at 0.525 (true value 0.5).
  • Path bb (Y ~ M) estimated at 0.769 (true value 0.7).
  • Path cc (Y ~ X) estimated at -0.060. The 95% Credible Interval [-0.296, 0.176] includes zero, correctly identifying that there is no direct effect.
  • Indirect Effect abab estimated at 0.401 (true value 0.35). The interval [0.218, 0.596] does not cross zero, indicating significant mediation.
  • Total Effect estimated at 0.331.
    • This is the sum of the direct and indirect effects (c+abc + ab).
    • It tells us that a 1-unit increase in XX leads to a total increase of roughly 0.331 in YY.
    • Note: In this simulation, even though the direct effect is non-significant (close to zero), the total effect is significant because the mechanism via MM is strong. This illustrates a “full mediation” scenario: XX affects YY, but only because of MM.

References

Yuan, Ying, and David P. MacKinnon. 2009. “Bayesian Mediation Analysis.” Psychological Methods 14 (4): 301–22. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0016972.
